content: How can I help you today?

I'm here because my wife insisted I see someone. Things have been really tough at home lately. My son has been acting out, and my wife and I can’t seem to agree on how to handle it. It’s been putting a huge strain on our marriage, and I just feel overwhelmed.

It sounds like there's been a lot weighing on you with everything happening at home. It must be tough navigating your son's behavior while also trying to make things work with your wife. How are you managing through all of this?

Honestly, I don't think I'm managing it well at all. I'm constantly stressed, and it feels like I'm failing everyone—my son, my wife, even my daughter because I barely have time or energy for her. I can't focus at work, and I don’t even enjoy the things I used to anymore. I don't know how to fix any of it.

It seems like you're carrying a heavy load and feeling pulled in so many directions, with work, your kids, and your relationship. Feeling like you're not able to give everyone what they need—and losing touch with things you once enjoyed—sounds exhausting and disheartening. What do you think has been the hardest part of all this for you?

I think the hardest part is feeling like I'm losing my family. My wife and I are arguing more, my son seems out of control, and I feel so disconnected from my daughter. It’s like no matter how hard I try, I'm not enough for any of them right now. That’s really been tearing me apart.

It sounds devastating to feel like you're losing the connection with your family, especially when you're trying so hard to hold everything together. It makes sense that this would weigh heavily on you, given how much you care about them. What are some ways you've been trying to support them, or yourself, during these challenging times?

Mostly, I just try to be there, but it feels like nothing I’m doing helps. I try to talk to my son, but it turns into arguments or he just shuts me out. With my wife, I try to listen, but we end up blaming each other. And with my daughter, I just... I don’t even know where to start when I feel so drained all the time. Honestly, I don’t think I’ve done anything to take care of myself through all of this.

Trying to be present for everyone while feeling drained sounds incredibly challenging, especially when things aren't going as you'd hoped. It seems like you're giving so much of yourself, yet feeling disconnected—and it's really taking a toll. What do you think would help you feel less drained or bring some relief, even just for a moment?

I'm not even sure anymore. I feel like I've forgotten what relief even feels like. Maybe just having someone to understand what I'm going through would help. Right now, I just feel stuck, like I'm in a constant cycle with no way out.

Feeling stuck and alone in this cycle sounds deeply isolating, and it's understandable that simply feeling understood could provide some relief. Being caught in a place like this can make it hard to envision what change or progress might look like. What do you think you might want for yourself or your family, if you could step out of this cycle?

I just want things to feel normal again. I want to help my son, find a way for my wife and me to stop fighting all the time, and to spend time with my daughter without feeling guilty. I want us to feel like a family again. But right now, I don’t even know where to start or if it’s even possible.

Wanting to reconnect with your family and bring back that sense of normalcy sounds really important to you, even if it feels out of reach right now. The fact that you're expressing what you want shows how much you care. What do you think might be one small step toward moving in that direction—or even exploring if it’s possible?

I really don’t know what the first step would be. Maybe figuring out how to help my son would be a start? It feels like if we could understand what’s going on with him and help him, then maybe everything else would get a little better too. But I don’t know how to do that.

Focusing on understanding and supporting your son sounds like a meaningful first step, especially since it feels connected to the challenges you're facing as a family. It’s okay not to have all the answers right now—it’s a process. Is there anything you feel you’d like to talk about or explore further before we consider ways to approach this together?

I think just figuring out why he's acting out would help. Maybe it's something we're missing, or something going on that he can't explain. I feel like if we could get to the bottom of it, then maybe we could actually do something to help him.

It sounds like you’re really committed to understanding your son and figuring out what’s beneath the surface of his behavior—which shows how much you care and want to support him. Sometimes behaviors can be a way of expressing things that are hard to say. Would it be helpful to think about ways to gently begin exploring what’s going on with him—or even steps toward creating space for that conversation to happen?

It sounds like trying to understand your son better is really important to you, and you're right—there’s often more beneath the behavior. Creating space for him to share could be a good step, but it might also be helpful to get professional support, like a counselor or therapist who specializes in working with kids. What do you think about that idea?

It could be helpful to get professional support, but the idea of talking to someone like that for him or even for your family might bring up different emotions or questions. Would you like to explore that further, or do you want to think about home-based approaches first?

Yeah, maybe that would help him, especially since we haven’t been able to figure it out on our own. I think it’d be worth trying, but I’d need to talk to my wife about it too. It’s hard to know where to start, though—do you think that could really make a difference?

Seeking guidance from a professional who specializes in understanding kids’ behavior and emotions can often provide valuable insights and tools. It could also offer both you and your wife support as parents, which might help ease some of the strain you're feeling. It’s great that you’re open to exploring this option—you’re already taking steps toward helping your family. Would it be helpful to brainstorm how to approach this conversation with your wife?
